name: Ann Henry
comments: Singer, dancer, choreographer, impressionist, and comedienne from Chicago. She was an all-around entertainer who was billed as "the female "Sammy Davis, Jr." She was the originator of the Co-op Dance Group in Chicago. Her big break came when she replaced Eartha Kitt in the musical revue, "New Faces of 1952." Subsequently, she was hired to become a member of the original cast of "New Faces of 1956." By 1959 she had a successful television show in London. On returning to the U.S. she performed in Las Vegas night clubs. In the mid 1960s she was hospitalized for spinal meningitis. After two years of treatment she had partially recovered and was able to move to Mount Angel Abbey in Oregon where she became a musical composer-in-residence.

name: Jeffrey Lau

Lau is a pioneer of the so-called Mo lei tau ("Makes no sense"), a genre that developed in Hong Kong during the late 20th century. Mo lei tau (and Lau's films in general) mixes slapstick humor, dialogues full of Cantonese wordplays, parodies (and self-parodies), anachronisms, and cross references.

Five of his seven albums gained top 5 status in Germany (two even No. 1 and one No. 2) and he has been awarded with two Echos (German Grammy). Gentleman also collaborates and releases joint records with numerous famous Jamaican and European reggae artists.

name: William Clauson
comments: Swedish-American Folk singer from Ashtabula, Ohio. His family had emigrated to the United States but returned temporarily to Sweden where William Clauson lived between the ages of two and six years old. On returning to the U.S. his family lived in Los Angeles, California. He studied violin, voice and composition at a conservatory. Later he gave up the violin and studied the guitar. In the 1940s he was an actor and appeared in an Abbot and Costello film. However, he decided to pursue a career in music. He travelled extensively performing and recording in many countries including Mexico, Australia, New Zealand and Scandinavian countries.

name: Kaj Chydenius
comments: Prolific composer and songwriter. Chydenius was one of the leading lights of a left-wing avant-garde movement that emerged from the Sibelius Academy in the early to mid 1960s, influenced by composers such as John Cage, Luigi Nono and György Ligeti. Initially working in musical theatre and political cabaret, his compositions include works for stage and screen, operas, choral works, poems set to music and political, romantic and children's songs. His album "Lauluja" was the first LP to be released by the new label Love Records , and in the intervening years several of his songs have become standards in Finland.
